resources.string: CSV file of drink history saved.
Select a drink and click on it.

Thanks for choosing Caffeine Counter! 


Most of the functions on this app should be self-explanatory. You can add drinks, edit/delete them by selecting Menu/History, clicking the date of the drink, and clicking the drink. You can also plot your daily caffeine history (once you have 2 days of data) by selecting Menu/Plot, and save or email a CSV file with your drink data (if you want to view it in a spreadsheet program like Excel) by selecting Menu/More/Save CSV. 


You can also add new drink types to the database, either by pressing "Drink Not Found" in the drink selector view, or by navigating to Menu/More/Drink Types/Add New Drink in the menu. If you click on "Drink Not Found" you will be directed to www.energyfiend.com where you can select a drink type. Once you select a drink you will be prompted to add the drink to the database. Press the Add button and a dialog will appear with the values of that drink inserted in the fields. Simply press the Enter button and the drink will be added to your database. If you navigate to Menu/More/DrinkTypes/Add New Drink the Add Drink dialog will appear, but you will have to supply the name and caffeine amounts yourself.


The app's default is to vibrate whenever you add a drink that goes over your daily caffeine limit. You can turn this off/on at Menu/More/Disable Vibrate. The app will reward you with certificates (of no value) when you keep under your limit for various lengths of time. You can turn this off at Menu/More/Disable Rewards. 


Caffeine amounts were obtained from the following sources:


	http://www.energyfiend.com

 	"Nutrition by the Cup", Starbucks drink nutrition guide (available at any Starbucks store). 


These were converted (when needed) to a per oz amount. You can view or edit these amounts by selecting the Menu/Drink Types menu option (For Starbucks, to see/edit the amounts, select the drink on Drink Types menu). There you can also add new drink types (provided you know the caffeine amounts).


This app also can display values in metric units. However, sizes and caffeine amounts for the drinks are stored using ounces and are simply converted to the corresponding values in milliters for display. 


The Mayo Clinic (http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/caffeine/NU00600) recommends keeping to 200-300mg of caffeine a day. Caffeine Counter's limit can be changed to a different value by selecting "Change Limit" in the menu options.


If you have any questions, suggestions or other comments feel free to email the developer at detroitteatime@gmail.com.
